KXDgc6HP.title: An extended network via hydrogen bond linkage of the linear coordination polymer [Cd(μ-dptz)(NO3)2]∞
KXDgc6HP.abstract: The crystal structure of [Cd(μ-dptz)(NO3)2]∞ reveals a neutral one-dimensional coordination polymer exhibiting a two-dimensional architecture through inter-chain hydrogen-bonding.

5MhTsiXW.title: Unusual anion effect on the direction of three-dimensional (3-D) channel-like silver(I) coordination frameworks with isonicotinic acid N-oxide

EB7riXSV.title: A new dinuclear copper(II) complex of a bis-macrocyclic ligand: Synthesis, characterization, crystal structure and magnetic properties
EB7riXSV.abstract: A new dinuclear Cu(II) complex, [Cu2L(N3)2] (ClO4)1.5 · (OH)0.5 · 2H2O · 0.5C2H5OH (1), of a bis-macrocyclic ligand, 2,6-bis(1,4,7,10-tetraazacyclododecan-10-ylmethyl)-methoxybenzene (L), has been synthesized, characterized and structurally determined by X-ray diffraction analysis. Complex 1 crystallizes in orthorhombic crystal system, Pca2(1) space group with a = 1.5371(3), b = 1.6641(3), c = 3.0950(6) nm, V = 7.917(3) nm3, Fw = 904.62, Z = 8, Dc = 1.529 g/cm3, and final R = 0.0568, wR = 0.1406 for 10410 observed reflections with I≥2σ. (I). Both Cu(II) centers in the structure are coordinated by four nitrogen atoms of 1, 4, 7, 10-tetraazacyclododecane (cyclen) and a nitrogen donor of the axial azide anion. Each Cu(II) center is in a square-pyramidal coordination environment, and the intra-and nearest inter-molecular Cu···Cu nonbonding distances are 0.9855 and 0.7298 nm, respectively. Variable temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements in the range of 4.2-300 K indicate that there exists weak intra- and inter-molecular antiferromagnetic coupling between the Cu(II) centers with 2J = -4.2 cm-1 and Θ = -0.47 K.

y2k7VXtH.title: Cocrystallization of bent dipyridyl type compounds with aromatic dicarboxylic acids: Effect of the geometries of building blocks on hydrogen-bonding supramolecular patterns
y2k7VXtH.abstract: The high-yielding preparation and X-ray structures of six 1:1 molecular cocrystals consisting of bent dipyridyl bases and aromatic dicarboxylic acids, including [phthalic acid]·[3-bpo] (1), [phthalic acid]·[4-bpo] (2), [isophthalic acid]·[3-bpo] (3), [isophthalic acid]·[4-bpo] (4), [terephthalic acid]·[3-bpo] (5), and [terephthalic acid]· [4-bpo] (6), are described, in which 3-bpo refers to 2,5-bis(3-pyridyl)-1,3,4- oxadiazole and 4-bpo its 4-N-donor analogue 2,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazole. A supramolecular synthon I [R2 2(7)] containing classical O-H⋯N and weak C-H⋯O interactions, usually observed in organic cocrystals of carboxylic acids with other heterocyclic bases, is again shown to be involved in constructing most of these hydrogen-bonding networks. In compounds 3-5, tapes of acid/base components are formed via synthon I, which are further extended to result in two-dimensional (2-D) supramolecular sheets via additional C-H⋯O interactions. Compound 2 contains similar but helical tapes with synthon I, and the neighboring twisted chains are cross-linked via weak C-H⋯O hydrogen bonds to show a 2-D corrugated network. Compound 6 contains a similar 2-D layered structure to that of 3-5, although synthon I was not found due to the stereochemistry effect. Unexpectedly, adjacent layers are further combined into a three-dimensional (3-D) architecture through acid-base C-H⋯O hydrogen bonds. However, in compound 1, through intermolecular O-H⋯N and C-H⋯O bonds, a novel 3-D structure was formed, in which acid and base subunits arrange alternately to exhibit a helical motif along the crystallographic [100] direction. For all these cocrystals, the common head-to-tail hydrogen-bonded ring motif [synthon II R2 2(8)] between carboxylic acids is absent. Melting points of cocrystals 1-6 are mainly correlated with the nature of the acid component and crystal packing. Thermogravimetric analysis of mass loss for six compounds has been shown to correlate with the strength of hydrogen bonds in the packing fraction. © 2005 American Chemical Society.

bPVXPJqH.title: A New Polymorph of the Co~(II) Perchlorate Supramolecular Complex with 2,5-Bis(4-pyridyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazole
bPVXPJqH.abstract: The reaction of 2,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazole(4-bpo) with Co(ClO_4)_2 in the presence of succinic acid and triethylamine affords a new polymorph of [Co(4-bpo)_2(H_2O)_4](4-bpo)_2(ClO_4)_2(H_2O)_6(1).It crystallizes in monoclinic system,space group P2/n with a=1.909 2(2) nm,b=0.699 7(8) nm,c=2.271 1(3) nm,β=98.462(2)~o,(V=3.000 6(6) nm~3,)Z=2.In the discrete coordinated entity, the octahedral Co~(II) is located at the inversion center,consisting of four equatorial water molecules and two axial pyridyl N donors from 4-bpo.The monomeric([Co(4-bpo)_2(H_2O)_4]~(2+)) cations are surrounded by the lattice water,4-bpo and perchlorate,which are interlinked by multiple O-H…O and O-H…N interactions to show a novel host-guest inclusion with the counter anions lying within and between the 2-D hydrogen-bonded arrays.

kfOdeVRX.title: Structural and first magnetic characterization of unique mono-μ-chloro bridged dinuclear CuII complexes with heterocycle-functionalized diazamesocyclic ligands
kfOdeVRX.abstract: Two new diazamesocyclic ligands based on 1,4-diazacycloheptane (DACH), functionalized by additional heterocyclic donor groups, 1,4-bis(pyridin-2-ylmethyl)-1,4-diazacycloheptane (L1) and 1,4-bis(imidazol-4-ylmethyl)-1,4-diazacycloheptane (L2), together with their CuII complexes [Cu2(μ-Cl)(L1)2](ClO4) 3 (1) and [Cu2(μ-Cl)(L2)2](ClO4) 3 (2), have been synthesized and characterized. Single crystal X-ray diffraction analyses revealed that both complexes have the unique mono-μ-Cl dimeric [Cu2(μ-Cl)(L)2]3+ structural motif. For both complexes, each CuII center is penta-coordinate in a distorted square-pyramidal environment with the bridging chloride atom at the apical position. The magnetic properties of mono-μ-chloro CuII dinuclear complexes have been investigated for the first time through the study of complexes 1 and 2 by variable temperature magnetic susceptibility and magnetization measurements. Weak ferromagnetic (for 1) or anti-ferromagnetic (for 2) interactions between the two CuII centers have been found and possible magneto-structural correlations have been analyzed.

U6XyT5ok.title: A Layered Cu~Ⅱ Coordination Polymer with Fluconazole:Synthesis,Characterization and Crystal Structure
U6XyT5ok.abstract: Assembly of copper(Ⅱ) chloride with fluconazole(HFlu) in the presence of tricyanomethanide(tcm,C(CN)3-) anion under general conditions in water/methanol media affords a metal-organic coordination polymer {[Cu(HFlu)2Cl2](H2O)4}n(1).It crystallizes in monoclinic system,space group C2/c with a=2.343 1(8) nm,b=0.945 6(3) nm,c=1.984(1) nm,β=123.444(4)o,V=3.668(3) nm3,and Z=4.Each CuⅡ center is coordinated to four triazole nitrogen atoms from distinct HFlu ligands and a pair of chloride anions,taking an octahedral geometry with typical Jahn-Teller distortion.The fluconazole molecules connect the adjacent CuⅡ ions to generate an undulated layered coordination framework.Hydrogen bonding interactions are also observed between the host framework and the included water guests to further sustain the whole crystalline lattice.

5UMbFgcX.title: Unprecedented 4- and 6-connected 2D coordination networks based on 4(4)-subnet tectons, showing unusual supramolecular motifs of rotaxane and helix.
5UMbFgcX.abstract: Two unprecedented 2D coordination polymers with 4- and 6-connected topological nets, arising from the different linkages of two adjacent 4(4) layers, were prepared from Co(II), 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane, and different isophthalate tectons.

X7dp0VBp.title: {[Dy2(bpdc)3(H2O)3] · H2O}n (bpdc = 2,2′-bipyridine-4,4′-dicarboxylate): A highly-thermostable 3D coordination polymer with unusual mixed-connected network topology
X7dp0VBp.abstract: A novel coordination polymer {[Dy 2 (bpdc) 3 (H 2 O) 3 ] · H 2 O} n has been successfully synthesized through hydrothermal route, which shows unusual mixed-connected network topology as well as high thermal stability and strong fluorescent emission. Abstract A novel 3D coordination polymer {[Dy 2 (bpdc) 3 (H 2 O) 3 ] · H 2 O} n (bpdc = 2,2′-bipyridine-4,4′- dicarboxylate) based on inorganic rod-shaped infinite secondary building unit is presented, which possesses unusual mixed-connected network topology and shows high thermal stability and strong photoluminescence at room temperature. Keywords Coordination polymer Network topology Thermal stability Luminescent property As an evergreen research area, the rational design and construction of coordination polymers has attracted considerable attention, which originates from their enthralling network topologies and potential applications in microelectronics, nonlinear optics, porous materials, catalysis, etc. [1–4] . Although the main goal in the field is to synthesize new functional crystalline materials, without the understanding of topology, it would be difficult to achieve another true advance [5] . In this sense, the effort on network topology will be one of the subjects of central importance within this area, which can precisely describe the complicated structures of extended solid-state materials [1,3,6] . Fortunately, Wells has classified the network structures in crystals and spawned the “vertices (metal ions/ligands)-and-spacer (linkers between vertices)” methodology [7] , which lays the foundation for general understanding of inorganic solids and metal–organic frameworks (MOFs). Up to now, a variety of uninodal coordination networks have been well realized, among which three-, four-, and six-connected topologies are commonly observed. Nevertheless, examples of five-, seven-, and eight-connected coordination frameworks remain scarce, due to the limited coordination numbers of metal centers and steric hindrance issues of organic ligands. In other ways, inspired by the prominent work of O’keeffee, Ramsden, Blatov, Robson, and their co-workers [1,7–9] , a valuable discovery is that the topological paradigms of some MOFs are consistent with those of the natural minerals, such as diamond, Pt 3 O 4 , boracite, CdSO 4 , PtS, CaB 6 , NbO, perovskite, pyrite, rutile, quartz, sodalite, SrSi 2 , CsCl, and tungsten bronze [2,5,10] . Meanwhile, some binodal networks have also been reported recently, such as (3,4)-, (3,5)-, (3,6)-, (3,9)-, (4,5)-, (4,8)-, (4,10)-, (5,6)-, and (6,8)-connected coordination frameworks [11] , and this will undoubtedly extend our understanding on such crystalline solids. Even now, there is an unfavorable lack of systematic and characteristic investigation on higher dimensional networks with mixed connectivity, especially multinodal networks suchlike (3,4,6)-, (3,4,8)-, (4,5,6)- and (3,4,5,6)-connected frameworks, which are considered to be difficult to achieve [12] . In fact, at this stage, there is few available experimental data to predict which, if any, of many thousands of possible topologies will dominate for each of these connected types. As a result, further studies on the design and assembly of MOFs with mixed connectivity will not only lead to an increasing emphasis towards identifying and classifying their underlying novel topologies, but also enrich the structural database of MOFs and extend their applied area. To address this issue, considering the limited number of coordination sites at the d-block metal centers, our strategy is to use f-block metal ions and multidentate ligands as nodes to construct periodic mixed-connected network. Herein, we report a highly-thermostable 3D coordination polymer {[Dy 2 (bpdc) 3 (H 2 O) 3 ] · H 2 O} n ( 1 ) (bpdc = 2,2′-bipyridine-4,4′-dicarboxylate) with unprecedented mixed-connected network structure. Compound 1 was prepared by hydrothermal method in 64% yield [13] and the structure was determined by X-ray single crystal diffraction [14] . Each asymmetric unit contains two Dy III ions, three bpdc anionic ligands, three aqua ligands, and one lattice water. The coordination environments of two crystallographically independent Dy III centers (Dy1 and Dy2) are shown in Fig. 1 , which are eight-coordinate but exhibit different coordination spheres ( Fig. S1 ). Dy1 is coordinated to seven carboxylate oxygen atoms from six carboxyl groups of bpdc and one terminal water oxygen atom, forming a slightly distorted dicapped trigonal prism polyhedron. Whereas Dy2 is in a dodecahedron geometry consisting of six carboxylate oxygen atoms from five carboxyl groups of bpdc and two water oxygen atoms. The Dy–O bond distances are in the range of 2.247(4)–2.756(3) Å for Dy–O carboxylate and 2.332(4)–2.426(3) Å for Dy–O water , which are comparable to those reported for other Dy–O donor complexes [15] . As for the bpdc ligands ( Fig. S2 ), the carboxylate groups take the syn–syn bridging and η -O , O ′-μ- O , O binding modes in types I and II ligands, respectively, whereas those in types III and IV that have imposed centrosymmetry, adopt the syn–anti bridging and unidentate fashions. Thus, the eight-coordinate Dy III ions are linked by carboxylate groups of bpdc to construct infinite 1D Dy–O–C chains running along the [0 0 1] direction, in which the Dy III ions are arranged in the nonlinear fashion. ( Figs. S3a and S3b ). These Dy–O–C chains, as rod-shaped infinite secondary building units (SBUs), are connected by types II and III ligands to form a 2D layer ( Fig. S3c ). The layers are further extended by type IV ligands and the SBUs between the layers are also cross-linked by type I ligands, generating a 3D noninterpenetrating network ( Figs. S4 and S5 ). It is noteworthy that in spite of the compact arrangement of the coordination framework, potential solvent accessible void (127.6 Å 3 , 6.8% of the cell volume as calculated by PLATON [16] ) is observed, in which the uncoordinated water molecules are situated ( Fig. S6 ). The presence and content of lattice water has also been confirmed by elemental analysis and thermogravimetric (TG) analysis. In addition, there still remains small interstice of 72.2 Å 3 (3.8% of the cell volume) for the overall crystalline lattice of 1 . In 1 , there exist strong π–π interactions between adjacent pyridyl rings of the bpdc ligands (the centroid⋯centroid distance between the pyridyl rings are 3.658(3) Å and 3.697(3) Å, with the dihedral angle of ca. 3.3°) ( Figs. S3c and S5a ). Meanwhile, the hydrogen-bonding interactions from coordinated water molecules to carboxylate oxygen atoms and from coordinated/guest water molecules to guest water molecules as well as pyridyl nitrogens are found ( Table S1 ). These weak interactions may contribute to the additional stability of the whole structure. Although the organic linker is long in 1 , it is evident that the close packed Dy–O–C chains connected by bpdc prevent the formation of an interpenetrating structure. This may also provide a clue that a layer-and-spacer approach may be useful to construct 3D metal–organic frameworks. In order to identify the complicated connectivity of the ligands and metal centers, the network topology of 1 is further analyzed. In this context, each Dy1 center is six-connected with vertex symbol of (4.4.4.4.4.6.6.6.6.6.6.6.7 3 .7 5 .8 8 ) and Dy2 is five-connected node with vertex symbol of (4.4.4.4.4.4.6.6.6 2 .6 2 ), and the ligands of types I, II, and III are four-connected nodes (3Dy1 + 1Dy2 for I, 2Dy1 + 2Dy2 for II, and 4Dy2 for III) with vertex symbols of (4.4 2 .4.7 2 .6 2 .6 2 ), (4.6.4 2 .4 2 .6 2 .6 2 ), and (4.4.4.4.6 2 .6 2 ), respectively. Notably, the type IV ligand is only a 2-connecting spacer. As a result, a very complicated 3D five-nodal coordination framework with (4,5,6)-mixed connectivity is formed ( Fig. 2 and Fig. S7 ), which has the Schläfli symbol of (4 3 .6 2 .7) 2 (4 3 .6 3 ) 2 (4 4 .6 2 )(4 5 .6 7 .7 2 .8) 2 (4 6 .6 4 ) 2 . Alternately, if we consider the familiar dimeric [Dy1(μ-O) 2 Dy2] subunits as the eight-connected nodes, and thus, the ligands of types I and III turn to three-connecting and four-connecting and the other ligands are two-connecting. In this case, the overall 3D network is three-nodal with the Schläfli symbol of (3 2 .4 2 .5 2 ) (3 2 .4 5 .5 4 .6 11 .7 6 ) 2 (4 2 .6) 2 , as shown in Figs. S8 and S7 . Therefore, the topological structure of 1 can be classified as a (4,5,6)-connected or (3,4,8)-connected 3D network. The unique topological net with mixed-connected node is rarely observed in coordination polymers up to now [1,12] . Recently, Peng et al. have enumerated a (3,4,5,6)-connected net [12b] based on polyoxometalates (POMs); Zhu et al. have reported a (3,4,6)-connected net, which adopts the octahedral, tetrahedral, and square SBUs as nodes, respectively [12d] . As far as we know, although some high-connected coordination networks, based on f-block metal ions and multicarboxylate ligands with diverse connectivity, have been demonstrated [11] , the net in 1 represents a new mixed-connected topology structure. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of compound 1 was performed in the atmosphere of nitrogen. The TGA trace ( Fig S9 ) illustrates that the guest water molecule is removed initially with increasing the temperature, and the loss of three coordinated water molecules then follows upon further heating to 145 °C (total weight loss of 6.38%, calcd 6.41%). In the temperature range of 145–480 °C, a weight loss of 4.36% may correspond to the release of 1 mol CO 2 per formula unit (calcd 4.00%), and this implies the possible decarboxylate reaction of the bpdc ligand [17] . The decomposition of the residual complex starts at 480 °C and ends at above 560 °C. The final product is assumed to be Dy 2 O 3 (found weight 32.97%), which is supported by the expected value of 33.20% and also confirmed by the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns (see Fig. S8 , beyond 500 °C, the diffraction peaks of Dy 2 O 3 appear). Notably, temperature-variable PXRD patterns of 1 (see Fig. S10 ) also reveal that the lattice structure is at least stable up to 400 °C, in which all water moieties have been excluded. The high coordination number and coordination tendency of lanthanide ions with the bpdc ligand should have a profound effect on the overall framework rigidity and thermal stability of 1 [18] , which may also arise from the significant π–π stacking interactions. Photoluminescence property of powder samples of 1 has also been examined at room temperature, which emits yellow light when excited at 340 nm. In the photoluminescence spectrum of 1 ( Fig. S11 ), the emission bands at 483, 577, and 667 nm indicate the characteristic behaviors of Dy 3+ ions, which are assigned to 4 F 9/2 → 6 H J ( J = 15/2, 13/2, and 11/2) transitions, respectively. Moreover, the yellow hypersensitive transition, 4 F 9/2 → 6 H 13/2 , as the preferred transition for dysprosium-containing luminescent materials, is more intense than the blue transition 4 F 9/2 → 6 H 15/2 in 1 . This can be attributed to the noncentrosymmetric coordination environment around the Dy centers [19] , and also implies that ligand is suitable for the sensitization of yellow luminescence for Dy 3+ ions [20] . In summary, a novel coordination polymer {[Dy 2 (bpdc) 3 (H 2 O) 3 ] · H 2 O} n has been successfully synthesized through hydrothermal route, which shows unusual mixed-connected network topology as well as high thermal stability and strong fluorescent emission. This work may offer a feasible strategy for rational combinations of different connectivity within a net structure, and may also enrich the family of lanthanide chemistry. H6ql804u.title: Alkali-metal-regulated construction of superhydrophilic ZnII and CdII coordination polymers with perhalogenated terephthalate ligands
H6ql804u.abstract: By simply introducing different alkali metal ions as structure-directing agents, four new coordination polymers with the formulae [Cd3(BDC- F4)3(DMF)2(MeOH)6]n (1), [Cd(BDC-F4)(DMF)2(H2O)2] n (2), [Zn2Na2(BDC-Cl4) 3(DMF)4(μ2-MeOH)]n (3) and [ZnK(BDC-Cl4)1.5(DMF)(Me2NH)]n (4) (BDC-F4 = 2,3,5,6-tetrafluoro-benzenedicarboxylate; BDC-Cl 4 = 2,3,5,6-tetrachloro-benzenedicarboxylate; DMF = dimethylformamide and Me2NH = dimethylamine) have been synthesized and structurally characterized. Complex 1 presents an open three-dimensional (3D) 3-nodal (3,4)-connected framework, 2 has a one-dimensional (1D) chain structure, 3 features a 3D 4-nodal (3,4,5,6)-connected coordination network constructed from the new ZnII-NaI heterometallic tetranuclear cluster, and 4 shows a 3D 4-nodal (3,5,6)-connected network based on the unique Zn II-KI heterometallic tetranuclear cluster. The results reveal the significant influence of alkali-metal ions on the structural topologies of complexes 1-4. Interestingly, compounds 1-4 all exhibit high water solubility, and futher evaporation of their water solution will result in a 1D coordination polymer {[Cd4(BDC-F4)4(H 2O)11]·3.5H2O}n (5) consisting of the unprecedented polymeric [CdII-H2O] n chain, and a zero-dimensional (0D) complex [Zn(H2O) 6]·(BDC-Cl4)·4H2O (6) containing the discrete [Zn(H2O)6]2+ cationic and BDC-Cl4 dianionic moieties. Furthermore, the solution chemistry of complexes 5 and 6 has been investigated by electrospray ionization (ESI) mass spectrometry and molar electrical conductivity. The photoluminescent properties of complexes 1-6 have also been explored, which interestingly indicate a strong blue emission of complex 1 in the solid state at room temperature. © 2013 The Royal Society of Chemistry.

4CvDsZUJ.title: From 1-D coordination polymers to 3-D hydrogen-bonding networks: Crystal engineering and magnetism of CuII-dca-cyanopyridine supramolecular systems (dca = dicyanamide, N(CN)2 -)
4CvDsZUJ.abstract: Three-dimensional (3-D) metallo-supramolecular architectures 1-3 based on CuII-dca-cypy systems [dca = dicyanamide, N(CN)2 -, and cypy = n-cyanopyridine (n = 4, 3, 2)], which are extended by combining metal-coordination and second-sphere hydrogen-bonded interactions, were rationally designed and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Reaction of CuII with dca and 4- or 3-cypy afforded two similar neutral one-dimensional (1-D) coordination polymers, [Cu(dca) 2(4-cypy)2]n (1) and [Cu(dca) 2(3-cypcy)2]n (2), in which the octahedral CuII centers are linked through double μ1,5-dca bridges and the cypy moieties act as monodentate terminal ligands via their pyridyl nitrogen donors. The coordination chains of 1 and 2 are further cross-linked by C-H⋯N interactions between the free nitrile N atoms of cypy and H atoms of the pyridyl ring, creating two interpenetrating 3-D networks (for 2, further weaker hydrogen-bonding interactions between the amide N atoms of dca and the H atoms in 3-cypy combined the two networks into a single net). When substituting the 4- or 3-cypy with 2-cypy, a single μ1,5-dca bridged 1-D chain [Cu(dca)2(pyom)]n (3) was isolated in which the square-pyramidal CuII center is chelated to the ligand O-methyl picolinimidate (pyom), generated from 2-cypy via addition of methanol across the C≡N group. These 1-D chains are further cross-linked by weak Cu-N dca interactions to form corrugated 2-D (6,3) sheets, which are highly interdigitated and further expanded to result in a 3-D network through interlayer C(N)-H⋯N interactions. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements reveal the existence of very weak antiferromagnetic or nil interactions between the CuII centers in complexes 1-3, and the magneto-structural correlations of such μ1,5-dca-Cu II 1-D systems are also discussed. © 2005 American Chemical Society.

kOcbeEhy.title: Ultra-highly selective trapping of perrhenate/pertechnetate by a flexible cationic coordination framework.
kOcbeEhy.abstract: The selective binding and trapping of perrhenate/pertechnetate is of great interest in the contamination remediation of nuclear waste. Herein, we report a cationic metal-organic framework (TJNU-216, TJNU = Tianjin Normal University), with ultra-high selectivity in trapping perrhenate/pertechnetate in the presence of a large excess of SO42- (20 000 times) or NO3- (300 times), and the highest exchange capacity of 417 mg g-1 (1 mol mol-1). The exchange mechanism can be confirmed by the crystal structure of TJNU-216(Re) via single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformation.

aVCANgc7.title: An unusual chain cadmium(II) -coordination polymer: Catena-poly[[(2, 2′-bipyridyl-κ2 N,N′)cadmium(II)]-di - Chlorido-[(2,2′-bipyridyl-κ2 N,N′)cadmium(II)]-di -μ Thiocyanato-κ2 N:S;κ2 S:N]
aVCANgc7.abstract: The title complex, [CdCl(NCS)(C10H8N2)] n , represents an unusual Cd II coordination polymer constructed by two types of anionic bridges and 2,2′-bipyridyl (bipy) terminal ligands. These two types of bridges are arranged around inversion centers. The distorted octa-hedral coordination of the CdII center is provided by two chloride ions, one N- and one S-donor atom from two thio-cyanate ions, and a pair of N atoms from the chelating bipy ligand. Inter-estingly, adjacent CdII ions are inter-connected alternately by paired chloride [Cd⋯Cd = 3.916 (1) Å] and thio-cyanate bridges [Cd⋯Cd = 5.936 (1) Å] to generate an infinite one-dimensional coordination chain. Furthermore, weak inter-chain C - H⋯S inter-actions between the bipy components and thio-cyanate ions lead to the formation of a layered supra-molecular structure. © International Union of Crystallography 2007.

SlNHmwgt.title: Formation of cobalt(II)–piperazine supramolecular systems under different organic acid mediums: synthesis, characterization and crystal structures
SlNHmwgt.abstract: The reactions of CoCl 2 salt and piperazine ( L ) in the presence of different organic acid mediums afford a series of cobalt(II) complexes, the solid structures (determined by X-ray diffraction techniques) of which are controlled by the nature of the specific acid. When terephthalic acid was used, a novel mononuclear molecule [Co(H L ) 2 Cl 3 ]·Cl·(H 2 O) ( 1 ) was obtained [orthorhombic, Pnma , a =24.604(16) Å, b =9.882(7) Å, c =6.609(4) Å, Z =4], in which the Co II center takes the unusual compressed trigonal-bipyramidal coordination geometry (CoN 2 Cl 3 ) and multiple hydrogen-bonding interactions extend this structure into a three-dimensional supramolecular network. However, with the replacement of terephthalic acid with malonic acid in the above reaction, a one-dimensional coordination polymer [Co L Cl 2 ] n ( 2 ) was obtained [monoclinic, P 2 1 / n , a =6.363(3) Å, b =10.244(5) Å, c =12.124(5) Å, β =103.560(8)°, Z =4], in which the tetrahedral Co II centers (CoCl 2 N 2 ) are linked by the bidentate-coordinated piperazine molecules to form a zigzag chain array and these coordination chains are further expanded to a three-dimensional hydrogen-bonding architecture. In addition, a mononuclear complex [Co(gly) 3 ]·(H 2 O) ( 3 ) [monoclinic, P 2 1 / c , a =6.261(5) Å, b =14.280(9) Å, c =12.182(8) Å, β =101.450(14)°, Z =4] was yielded when glycine was used in the similar procedure. A three-dimensional framework is also observed through the hydrogen-bonding interactions between [Co(gly) 3 ] moieties, in which the guest water molecules are included. These results unequivocally indicate that the nature of the organic acid templates play the key role in formation of these complexes. Keywords Crystal structure Piperazine Hydrogen bond Self-assembly Organic acid medium 1 Introduction Self-assembly processes involving metal ions and organic ligands directed by either metal coordination or hydrogen bonds have attracted much attention in the field of supramolecular chemistry and crystal engineering from the viewpoints of the development of novel functional materials with desired properties [1–5] . Although the general and precise principles for controlling the solid structures of the target products are still needed to be classified and established, many rational synthetic strategies have been brought forward and proved significant in the approach of the design of the metal-based coordination supramolecules. The selection of proper ligands as ‘building blocks’, such as the most common 4,4′-bipyridyl-based ligands, is undoubtedly a key point in manipulating the network structures [6] , and other factors such as metal ion, counter anion, solvent, metal/ligand ratio and even pH value have also been found to highly influence the structural topologies of such coordination frameworks [7] . Recently, a series interesting coordination supramolecules, [{M(BTEC)(H 2 O) 4 }]·{H 2 L }·4H 2 O] n (M=Co II , Ni II and Zn II ; BTEC=1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylate), were reported by Murugavel et al., [8] , which exhibit the anionic metal-organic and cationic organic layer alternated architecture. In these compounds, the metal centers coordinate to the BTEC molecules, and the protonated piperazine moieties act as the cation templates in the formation of the final products. Additionally, Tran Qui and Palacios have reported the crystal structure of [H 2 L ]·[CoCl 4 ]·4H 2 O prepared by CoCl 2 and L in the presence of HCl [9] , which consists of a bis -protonated H 2 L cation, CoCl 4 mononuclear anionic unit and solvents, and a hydrogen-bonding three-dimensional supramolecular network is observed. To further develop such metal-based supramolecular systems, we select terephthalic acid, malonic acid or glycine (see Chart 1 ) instead of BTEC or HCl to assemble with Co II salt and piperazine. In each case, other reacting conditions are kept constant, and the only varied parameter during these processes is the organic acid medium. Our results indicate that the nature of the organic acid templates play the key role in formation of the complexes [Co(H L ) 2 Cl 3 ]·Cl·(H 2 O) ( 1 ), [Co L Cl 2 ] n ( 2 ) and [Co(gly) 3 ]·(H 2 O) ( 3 ) with different supramolecular architectures, as described in the present paper. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and general methods All reagents for synthesis and analysis were obtained commercially with analytical grade and used as received. FT-IR spectra (KBr pellets) were taken on a FT-IR 170SX (Nicolet) spectrometer. Carbon, hydrogen and nitrogen analyses were performed on a Perkin–Elmer 240C analyzer. 2.2 Synthesis of complexes 1 – 3 2.2.1 [Co(HL) 2 Cl 3 ]·Cl·(H 2 O) (1) A dilute aqueous solution of CoCl 2 (87 mg, 0.2 mmol) was added to a solution of terephthalic acid (33 mg, 0.4 mmol) in DMF (20 ml). The mixture was heated to 80 °C under stirring for ca. 30 min to obtain a light purple solution. Then, piperazine hexahydrate (116 mg, 0.6 mmol) in water (10 ml) was added slowly to the above hot solution with further stirring for 30 min, and the resultant purple solution was filtered after cooling to room temperature. Prism purple singe-crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained by slow evaporation of the solvents within two weeks in 40% yield. Found: C, 24.3; H, 6.1; N, 14.4%. Calc. for C 8 H 24 Cl 4 CoN 4 O: C, 24.5; H, 6.2; N, 14.3%. FT-IR (KBr pellet, cm −1 ): 3485b, 3238s, 3212m, 3114m, 3005w, 2982w, 2954w, 2816m, 2793m, 2723m, 2643m, 2486w, 2315w, 2192w, 1959w, 1614vs, 1595vs, 1490w, 1450vs, 1434s, 1377s, 1315w, 1228w, 1205m, 1100s, 1087m, 1068m, 1007vs, 953w, 871s, 816m, 738m, 600w, 572w, 478m. 2.2.2 [CoLCl 2 ] n (2) The same synthetic procedure as for 1 was used except that terephthalic acid was replaced by malonic acid, resulting in prism violet single-crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction in 65% yield. Found: C, 22.4; H, 4.8; N, 13.4%. Calc. for C 4 H 10 Cl 2 CoN 2 : C, 22.2; H, 4.7; N, 13.0%. FT-IR (KBr pellet, cm −1 ): 3247m, 3031m, 2872w, 2805w, 2762w, 2663w, 2464w, 1685m, 1636vs, 1581vs, 1490m, 1431s, 1397s, 1369s, 1342w, 1269s, 1161w, 1122w, 1087m, 982m, 956s, 866m, 774s, 734s, 677w, 582m, 488w. 2.2.3 [Co(gly) 3 ]·(H 2 O) (3) The same synthetic procedure as for 1 was used except that terephthalic acid was replaced by glycine, giving block pink single-crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction in 50% yield. Found: C, 23.7; H, 4.3; N, 14.3%. Calc. for C 6 H 14 CoN 3 O 7 : C, 24.1; H, 4.7; N, 14.1%. FT-IR (KBr pellet, cm −1 ): 3444b, 3224b, 3133m, 2949w, 2170w, 1683vs, 1635vs, 1597vs, 1424m, 1393s, 1371vs, 1324s, 1315s, 1215s, 1178s, 1155m, 1031w, 964m, 919m, 816m, 779m, 747w, 608m, 594m, 574w, 540w, 505w. 2.3 Crystallographic data collection and structure determination Single-crystal X-ray diffraction study of complexes 1 – 3 were performed on a BRUKER SMART 1000 CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite crystal monochromator situated in the incident beam for data collection. The determination of unit cell parameters and data collections were performed with Mo Kα radiation ( λ =0.71073 Å) by ϖ scan mode in the range of 2.64< θ <25.68° (for 1 ), 2.63< θ <25.64° (for 2 ) and 3.32< θ <20.35° (for 3 ) at 293(2) K. All data were corrected by semi-empirical method using SADABS program. The program SAINT [10] was used for integration of the diffraction profiles. All structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXS program of the SHELXTL-97 package and refined with SHELXL [11] . Co II centers were located from the E-maps and other non-hydrogen atoms were located in successive difference Fourier syntheses. The final refinements were performed by full matrix least-squares methods with anisotropic thermal parameters for non-hydrogen atoms on F 2 . All the hydrogen atoms were first found in difference electron density maps, and then placed in the calculated sites and included in the final refinement in the riding model approximation with displacement parameters derived from the parent atoms to which they were bonded. The refinements converged to final R =0.0385, wR =0.0799, S =1.045, ( Δ / σ ) max =0.002, ( Δ / σ ) min =0.000 (for 1 ); R =0.0420, wR =0.0791, S =1.027, ( Δ / σ ) max =( Δ / σ ) min =0.000 (for 2 ); and R =0.0575, wR =0.0907, S =0.991, ( Δ / σ ) max =( Δ / σ ) min =0.000 (for 3 ). The ratios of minimum to maximum apparent transmission are 0.7305 (for 1 ), 0.7278 (for 2 ) and 0.7843 (for 3 ), respectively. Molecular graphics were drawn with the program package XP. Further crystallographic data and experimental details for structural analyses of the three complexes are summarized in Table 1 , and selected bond lengths and angles with their estimated standard deviations for complexes 1 – 3 in Tables 2–4 , respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Description of the crystal structures of complexes 1 – 3 3.1.1 [Co(HL) 2 Cl 3 ]·Cl·(H 2 O) (1) The crystal structure of 1 consists of a discrete mononuclear [Co(H L ) 2 Cl 3 ] + cation with a symmetry mirror through Co(1)–N(1)–N(3)–Cl(1) plane, a chloride anion and a lattice water molecule. The ORTEP view of the coordination cation in complex 1 with atom labeling is shown in Fig. 1a . The coordination geometry around the Co II center could be described as a compressed trigonal-bipyramidal generated by N(1)–N(3)–Cl(1)–Cl(2)–Cl(2A) with τ value of 0.88, which is used to describe the degree of distortion for penta-coordinated complexes ( τ =1 for an ideal trigonal-bipyramid and τ =0 for an ideal square-pyramid) [12,13] . Two nitrogen atoms of distinct piperazine rings act as the axis with the mean Co–N distance of 2.195(5) Å, and three chloride anions are composed of the basal plane with the mean Co–N distance of 2.320(2) Å (Co II ion is deviated from this mean coordination plane by only 0.0078 Å). Two protonated piperazine rings are in normal chair conformation, which are both slightly distorted from ideal (the ring torsion angles lying in the range of 51.8(6)–59.9(6)°), and take the monodendate coordination mode with the central Co II ion due to the protonation of one nitrogen donor. The average C–C and C–N bond lengths of the piperazine rings are 1.507(6) and 1.472(5) Å, respectively. Analysis of the crystal packing of complex 1 in the unit cell shows that there exist multiple hydrogen-bonding interactions, resulting in a three-dimensional supramolecular network. As shown in Fig. 1b , a pair of N(2)–H(2B)–Cl(2) i,ii (i= x , y , z −1; ii= x ,− y +1/2, z −1) hydrogen bonds, together with the N(3)–H(3C)–Cl(1) iii (iii= x , y , z +1), between one protonated piperazine ring and the adjacent coordinated chloride anion link the [Co(H L ) 2 Cl 3 ] + cations to form a one-dimensional chain motif along [001] direction. Meantime, the uncoordinated Cl(3) anion acts as a three-connected node through N(1)–H(1C)–Cl(3) iv (iv=− x +1/2,− y +1, z +1/2), N(2)–H(2A)–Cl(3) v (v=− x +1/2,− y +1, z −1/2) and N(4)–H(4B)–Cl(3) vi (vi=− x ,− y +1,− z +2) interactions, linked the adjacent chains to form a two-dimensional layered architecture along (101) plane ( Fig. 1b ). In addition, the lattice water molecules in each layer form intra-layered N(4)–H(4A)–O(1) vii (vii=− x ,− y +1,− z +1) bonds with the adjacent piperazine rings, and further expand these layers through [010] direction to form a three-dimensional framework via two types inter-layered O(1)–H(1)–Cl(2) ii and O(1)–H(2)–Cl(2) viii (viii= x , y +1, z −1) interactions. For all the hydrogen bonds stated above, the N⋯Cl separations are in 3.056–3.402 Å range, the N⋯O and O⋯Cl separations are 2.739 and 3.126 Å, respectively; and the smallest bond angle is 135.7°, falling into the normal range of such weak hydrogen-bonding interactions [14] . 3.1.2 [CoLCl 2 ] n (2) X-ray single crystal structure determination reveals that complex 2 is a neutral one-dimensional infinite zigzag coordination chain as shown in Fig. 2a . Each Co II center coordinates to two N donors of distinct piperazine rings and two chloride anions, forming a tetrahedral coordination sphere. The CoCl 2 moiety is preserved within this complex: Co(1)–Cl(1) and Co(1)–Cl(2) bond distances are 2.243(2) and 2.242(2) Å, respectively, accompanied by a Cl(1)–Co(1)–Cl(2) angle of 105.38(6)°. The piperazine rings in this structure also take the usual chair conformation, which are both slightly distorted from ideal (the ring torsion angles lying in the range of 52.5(5)–55.5(6)°), bridging the Co II centers via two nitrogen donors to form a one-dimensional zigzag coordination polymer along [001] direction. The average C–C and C–N bond lengths of the piperazine rings are 1.510(6) and 1.481(5) Å, respectively, agreeing with the values in 1 . In this 1:1 ligand/metal polymeric chain, the neighboring Co(1)⋯Co(1A) separation (bridged by piperazine ring) is 6.862 Å and the Co(1)⋯Co(1B) distance is 12.124 Å. In addition, the shortest Co⋯Co (symmetry codes: − x +1/2, y −1/2, − z −1/2; − x +1/2, y +1/2, − z −1/2) distance between the adjacent chains is only 5.425 Å. Analysis of the crystal packing of 2 in the unit cell indicates that four independent inter-chain N–H⋯Cl hydrogen bonds link these one-dimensional coordination chains to result in a three-dimensional architecture as depicted in Fig. 2b . The N(1)–H(1C) group in one piperazine ring of each coordination chain forms two N–H⋯Cl hydrogen bonds with chloride anions of two adjacent distinct coordination chains: N(1)–H(1C)⋯Cl(2) i (i= x −1, y , z ) and N(1)–H(1C)⋯Cl(1) ii (ii=− x −1/2, y −1/2, − z +3/2). Meantime, the N(2)–H(2C) group in the other piperazine ring of each coordination chain also forms two N–H⋯Cl hydrogen bonds, however, with chloride anions of one adjacent coordination chain: N(2)–H(2C)⋯Cl(2) iii and N(2)–H(2C)⋯Cl(1) iii (iii=− x +1/2, y −1/2,− z +3/2). All the N⋯Cl separations are in 3.436–3.627 Å range with H⋯Cl separations in 2.701–2.939 Å region, respectively; and the smallest bond angle is 133.5°, falling into the normal range of such weak hydrogen-bonding interactions [14] . 3.1.3 [Co(gly) 3 ]·(H 2 O) (3) The crystal structure of compound 3 consists of one isolated neutral [Co(gly) 3 ] unit and a lattice water molecule. Two crystallography isomers (monoclinic, P 2 1 / n , a =13.860(3) Å, b =13.153(3) Å, c =13.996(3) Å, β =112.88(1)°, Z =8; orthorhombic, Pna 2 1 , a =15.331(2) Å, b =13.205(2) Å, c =11.606(2) Å, Z =8) of a very similar compound [Co(gly) 3 ]·(H 2 O) 2 were reported previously [15,16] . The [Co(gly) 3 ] molecule with atom numbering scheme is presented in Fig. 3a . The Co II center coordinates to three chelated gly ligands (each with one N donor of the –NH 2 group and one O atom of the monodendate –COO − group), forming a distorted octahedral stereochemistry. The average Co–N and Co–O distances are 1.935(5) and 1.916(4) Å, respectively, which are comparable to other similar compounds [15–17] . Analysis of the crystal packing of 3 in the unit cell indicates the existence of six intermolecular N–H⋯O hydrogen bonds between the –NH 2 and –COO − groups of the gly molecules: N(1)–H(1A)⋯O(5) i (i= x +1, y , z ), N(1)–H(1A)⋯O(2) ii (ii= x ,− y +1/2, z −1/2), N(1)–H(1B)⋯O(4) iii (ii=− x +1,− y +1,− z +1), N(2)–H(2A)⋯O(1) ii , N(2)–H(2B)⋯O(2) iv (iv= x −1,− y +1/2, z −1/2) and N(3)–H(3B)⋯O(6) i , resulting in a three-dimensional supramolecular network with cavities along [100] direction as depicted in Fig. 3b . The lattice water molecules are included in these channels with the formation of N(3)–H(3A)⋯O(7) ii , O(7)–H(7A)⋯O(3) and O(7)–H(7B)⋯O(6) v (v=− x , y +1/2,− z +3/2) hydrogen bonds with the host framework, which further stabilize this structure. All the N(O)⋯O separations are in 2.774–3.055 Å range with H⋯O separations in 2.074–2.310 Å region, respectively; and the smallest bond angle is 134.3°, falling into the normal range of such weak hydrogen-bonding interactions [14] . 3.2 Role of the organic acid in the self-assembly processes of complexes 1 – 3 From above descriptions, the choice of different organic acids is clearly critical in determining the molecular structures of the resultant complexes 1 – 3 . As stated in Section 1 , when 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylate or HCl was used in the self-assemblies process, the piperazine rings are bis -protonated and not involve in the coordination to the metal center. In this study, the nature of the acids is the underlying reason behind the differences in the structures of this series of Co II complexes. In complex 1 , the terephthalic acid causes the mono-protonation of the piperazine rings, and thus, prevents their further coordination with the Co II center to form a mononuclear complex. For complex 2 , the free piperazine rings bridge the Co II centers to form a one-dimensional coordination polymer. For compound 3 , the glycine moieties directly chelated with the Co II center to form a mononuclear molecule and the piperazine ring does not take part in the coordination. Additionally, a mononuclear Co II complex with N -methylpiperazine was reported recently [18] . Thus, direct coordination to metal centers is not the only role of the acids, and indeed extremely subtle templating effects to change the coordination modes of piperazine have also been observed in this study. 4 Conclusion and comments A series of Co II complexes 1 – 3 have been prepared by means of self-assemblies of CoCl 2 , piperazine and different organic acids, and structurally characterized by X-ray diffraction analyses. The resultant structures of these complexes are profoundly influenced by the organic acids, and different hydrogen-bonding supramoleclar architectures are observed, which can be utilized to advantage in supramolecular chemistry and crystal engineering. Further studies of the self-assemblies of such systems with other organic acids are under way in our laboratory. 4.1 Supplementary materials Crystallographic data for the crystal structures reported in this paper have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center (CCDC Nos. 225434/35/36). This material can be obtained free of charge via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.html (or from the CCDC, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK; fax: +44 1223 336033; e-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk). K8DdxXq5.title: Flexible building blocks of N,N′-bis(picolinoyl)hydrazine for hydrogen-bonding directed cocrystallization: Structural diversity, concomitant polymorphs, and synthon prediction
K8DdxXq5.abstract: Two new flexible dipyridyl building blocks, N,N′-bis(4-picolinoyl) hydrazine (4-bph) and its N-orientation isomer N,N′-bis(3-picolinoyl) hydrazine (3-bph), have been synthesized as versatile cocrystallizing agents and introduced into the reactions with pyromellitic acid (H4BTA) and fumaric acid (H2Fa). Hydrogen-bonded directed assemblies of two hydrates of bphs and four binary cocrystals were validated by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. With the presence of the reliable hydrogen-bonding donor/acceptor(s) of bph, the crystalline lattices of [4-bph]·2H 2O (1) and [3-bph]·2H2O (4) are managed by N-H⋯Owater and O-H⋯Ocarbonyl to afford one-dimensional (1D) arrays, which are further extended to distinct three-dimensional (3D) (for 1) and two-dimensional (2D) (for 4) networks via O-H⋯Npyridyl interactions. While for the concomitant polymorphs [(H2BTA)·(H2-4-bph)] (2 and 3), charge-assistant bifurcated N-H⋯O bonds do favor 1D acid-base hydrogen-bonding tapes, which are interlinked to result in a 2D layer in 2 and a 3D network in 3 through the competition of O-H⋯Ocarbonyl and O-H⋯Ocarbonyl forces. [(H3-BTA)2· (H2-3-bph)]·4H2O (5) is also a charge-transfer organic salt with a 2D bilayered array. Proton transfer from weak H 2Fa to 3-bph is not observed, and this leads to the formation of a binary neutral cocrystal [(H2Fa)·(3-bph)] (6), in which the 2D undulating herringbone pattern is constructed via the expected carboxylpyridyl heterosynthon and amide-amide homosynthon. © 2006 American Chemical Society.

Br4yJgex.title: Effect of Anions on the Framework Formation of Novel AgI Coordination Polymers with Angular Bridging Ligands
Br4yJgex.abstract: Coordination networks based on the organic ligand 2,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,3,4- thiadiazole (L1) or 2,5-bis(3-pyridyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazole (L 2) and various inorganic silver(I) salts were prepared and characterized by single-crystal X-ray analysis. Reaction of AgPF6 or AgClO4·H2O and L1 in CH 3OH/CHCl3 medium afforded a unique two-dimensional coordination polymer {[Ag(L1)](PF6)}∞ (1) or {[Ag(L1)](ClO4)}∞ (2) with (2/4,3) topology. However, with the replacement of AgPF6 or AgClO4·H2O with AgNO3 in the above reaction, an interesting three-dimensional coordination architecture {[Ag4(L 1)4(NO3)2](NO3) 2}∞ (3) constructed through weak interactions between nitrate ions and two different one-dimensional motifs was obtained. Furthermore, two one-dimensional coordination chains {[AgL1](CF3SO 3)}∞ (4) and {[Ag(L2)] (CF3SO 3)}∞ (5), with different structural geometries, were obtained by the reactions of AgCF3SO3 with L1 and L 2, respectively. The structural diversities of these complexes demonstrate that counteranions play essential roles in the construction of such supramolecular frameworks.

64MfqI3f.title: Preparation of acentric porous coordination frameworks from an interpenetrated diamondoid array through anion-exchange procedures: crystal structures and properties.
64MfqI3f.abstract: The formation, crystal structures, and properties of a series of three-dimensional (3-D) Cu(II) coordination polymers, [[Cu(L)2(H2O)2](PF6)2(H2O)(1.25)]n (1), [[CuL(N3)2](H2O)(1.5)]n (2), and [[CuL(H2O)(SO4)](H2O)2]n (3), with an angular bridging ligand 2,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazole (L) are reported. Complex 1 crystallizes in the tetragonal I4(1)/a space group (a = b = 13.462(2) A, c = 46.47(1) A, Z = 8), complex 2 in the orthorhombic Pna2(1) space group (a = 6.379(2) A, b = 10.060(3) A, c = 27.232(9) A, Z = 4), and complex 3 in the orthorhombic P2(1)2(1)2(1) space group (a = 5.510(2) A, b = 10.576(4) A, c = 28.34(1) A, Z = 4). Different polymeric frameworks are obtained by only varying the counterions. These include the 2-fold interpenetrated diamondoid structure of 1, the acentric alpha-Po network of 2, and the chiral open framework of 3 with (6(3)).(6(9).8) topology. The interesting anion-exchange, porous, and magnetic properties of these coordination supramolecules have been investigated in detail.

EV5TUUnn.title: Three-dimensional frameworks built from hydrogen bonds and π–π stacking interactions: structural and spectral study on Co(II) complexes of 1,5-diazacyclooctane (DACO) functionalized by heterocyclic pendants
EV5TUUnn.abstract: A series of Co(II) complexes of 1,5-diazacyclooctane (DACO) functionalized by imidazole or pyridine donor pendants have been synthesized and characterized. Each Co(II) center is penta-coordinated due to the boat/chair configuration of the DACO rings. Complexes 1 and 2 form different 3D network structures through hydrogen bonds and π–π stacking interaction. The solution behaviors have been further analyzed in detail.

AglQ02by.title: Ligand-to-metal ratio dependent assembly of two distinct 1D and 3D copper(II)-dicyanamide magnetic coordination polymers with a tripyridyltriazole co-tecton
AglQ02by.abstract: Assemblies of Cu(II) chloride with dicyanamide (dca) anion and a tripyridyltriazole co-ligand 3,4-bis(2-pyridyl)-5-(3-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole (L223) under different ligand-to-metal ratios produce two coordination polymers {[Cu5(L223)4(dca) 10](H2O)2}n (1) and [Cu(L 223)(dca)Cl]n (2), displaying distinct 1D double-chain array and 3D chiral dia network, respectively. Weak antiferromagnetic exchanges are observed in both coordination polymers. © 2013 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

4DcstIyL.title: Synthesis, spectroscopic and structural characterization of cobalt(II) complex with bis(3,5-dimethyl-1-pyrazolyl)methane and its application in catalytic alkanes oxidation with tert-butyl hydroperoxide
4DcstIyL.abstract: A novel cobalt complex, [Co(bdpm)(OBz)](ClO 4) (bdpm = bis(3,5-dimethyl-1-pyrazolyl)methane, OBz = benzoate), was synthesized and characterized by elemental analysis, UV-Vis, IR spectroscopy and X-ray diffraction. The complex crystallizes in the trigonal system, space group P3 121 with a = 19.2583(9), b = 19.2583(9), c = 25.5269(17) Å and γ = 120°. The complex can catalyze the selective oxidation of alkanes to corresponding alcohols and ketones, and a presumptive mechanism was proposed.

ZvMYvbK1.title: Diazido[bis(2-pyridyl)amine]zinc(II) hydrate, [Zn(C10H 9N3)2(N3)2]·H 2O
ZvMYvbK1.abstract: In mononuclear [Zn(C10H9N3) 2(N3)2]·H2O, the zinc atom has an approximate octahedral geometry, coordinated with four pyridyl nitrogen atoms derived from two bis(2-pyridyl)amine molecules and two terminal nitrogen donors of the azide anions. Hydrogen-bonding interactions extend this structure to form a double-layer architecture. Copyright © 2004 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.

mNRLA3yX.title: Novel boxlike dinuclear or chain polymeric silver(I) complexes with polypyridyl bridging ligands: Syntheses, crystal structures, and spectroscopic and electrochemical properties
mNRLA3yX.abstract: The syntheses, characterization, crystal structures, and photophysical and electrochemical properties of two dinuclear and two polymeric Ag(I) complexes with three polypyridyl ligands, 2,3-di-2-pyridylquinoxaline (L(1)), 2,3-di-2-pyridyl-5,8-dimethoxyquinoxaline (L(2)), and 2,3,7,8-tetrakis(2-pyridyl)pyrazino[2,3-g] quinoxaline (L(3)), are described. The structures of the two boxlike dinuclear complexes with L(1) and L(2) and two chemically the same but differently crystallized one-dimensional zigzag chain coordination polymers also consisting of boxlike dinuclear subunits have been elucidated by X-ray analysis. [AgL(1)(CH(3)CN)](2)-(BF(4))(2).2CHCl(3) (1): monoclinic, C2/c; a = 28.631(2), b = 12.2259(11), c = 14.3058(12) A; beta = 99.180(2) degrees; Z = 4. [AgL(2)(CH(3)CN)(2)](2)(ClO(4))(2) (2): triclinic, P1; a = 12.3398(2), b = 13.750(2), c = 14.326(7) A; alpha = 83.494(3), beta = 74.631(3), gamma = 76.422(3) degrees; Z = 4. [[Ag(2)L(3)(NO(3))(2)].CH(3)CN](infinity) (3a): monoclinic, P2(1)/c; a = 9.5836(8), b = 13.4691(12), c = 14.0423(12) A; beta = 107.753(2) degrees; Z = 4. [Ag(2)L(3)()(NO(3))(2)](infinity) (3b): monoclinic, P2(1)/c; a = 8.4689(6), b = 16.0447(12), c = 11.7307(8) A; beta = 102.051(1) degrees; Z = 2. The structures of the dinuclear complexes 1 and 2 are similar to each other, with the two intramolecular Ag(I) centers of each complex being spanned by two ligands thus forming a unique boxlike cyclic dimer. In 1, each Ag(I) center is four-coordinated by three nitrogen atoms of two L(1) ligands and a CH(3)CN nitrogen donor, taking a distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry. The coordination environment of Ag(I) in 2 is similar to that in 1, except the formation of an additional weak coordination bond with the oxygen atom of the methoxy group of L(2). The structures of 3a,b are very similar to each other, except for the stacking patterns in the crystal lattices, and the cyclic boxlike dinuclear unit, which is similar to the structure of 1, constitutes the fundamental building block to form the one-dimensional zigzag chain structures due to the "end-on" nature of L(3). 1-3 exhibit metal-perturbed intraligand transitions in solution in 360-390 nm regions. Cyclic voltammetric studies of these complexes show the presence of reduction peak at approximately -0.5 V vs Fc(+/0). In the solid state at 77 K, they exhibit broad emission that may be assignable to originate from the metal-perturbed intraligand transitions.

5TXKEosb.title: Metal-Involved solvothermal interconversions of pyrazinyl substituted azole derivatives: Controllability and mechanism
5TXKEosb.abstract: Under different solvothermal reaction conditions I (60 °C for 48 h) and II (140 °C for 72 h), the dipyrazinyl compounds bearing oxadiazole and triazole spacers, that is, 2,5-bis(2-pyrazinyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazole (L1) and 4-amino-3,5-bis(2-pyrazinyl)-1,2,4-triazole (L2), may suffer reversible conversions in the presence of certain metal salts. Other related derivatives such as 3,5-bis(2-pyrazinyl)-1,2,4-triazole-4-yl-N-pyrazinamide (HL4) and pyrazine-2-carboxylic acid (HL0) can also be (in situ) obtained from L1 and L2, respectively, under conditions I and II. Beyond this, N,N′-bis(2-pyrazineamide) (H 2L3) can be in situ afforded from both precursors L 1 and L2, and thus, may be considered as the potential intermediate during the interconversions. The possible mechanisms and influence factors of these reactions have also been established based on the experimental results. As a result, a variety of crystalline materials (co-crystals and coordination complexes) with attractive supramolecular architectures have been isolated by regulating the reaction conditions well (reaction temperature, metal ion, and even inorganic counteranion). © 2010 American Chemical Society.

qDGJ4Vra.title: Metal dicyanamide layered coordination polymers with cyanopyridine co-ligands: Synthesis, crystal structures and magnetism
qDGJ4Vra.abstract: A series of metal dicyanamide (dca) coordination polymers combined with cyanopyridine (cypy) terminal co-ligands, namely, [Co2(dca)4(4-cypy)4]n (1), [Cd(dca)2(4-cypy)2]n (2), [Fe(dca)2(3-cypy)2]n (3) and [Co(dca)2(3-cypy)2]n (4), have been synthesized at the ambient conditions. X-ray single crystal diffraction reveals that complexes 1-4 have similar metal-dca coordination layers in which the octahedral metal centers are connected by μ1,5-dca linkers. Notably, three types of 3-D packing lattices are observed for these layered arrays. The thermal stabilities of such new crystalline materials have been studied by thermogravimetric analysis of mass loss. The magnetic properties of the CoII and FeII complexes have been investigated and discussed in detail. A discrete mononuclear molecule [Cd(dca)2(pyom)2] (5) is also described, in which the chelated ligand O-methyl picolinimidate (pyom) arises from the addition of methanol solvent across the C{triple bond, long}N bond of 2-cypy. © 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.

HDP4FRXc.title: Structural and spectral studies on the Ni (II) complexes of 1,5-diazacyclooctane (DACO) bearing heterocyclic pendants: Formation of a two-dimensional network via hydrogen bonds and π-π stacking interactions
HDP4FRXc.abstract: A penta-coordinated Ni(II) complex with a 1,5-diazacyclooctane (DACO) ligand functionalized by two imidazole donor pendants, [NiL1Cl] (ClO4) · H2O (1) (where L1 = 1, 5-bis (imidazol-4-ylmethyl)-l,5-diazacyclooctane) has been synthesized and characterized by X-ray diffraction, infrared spectra, elemental analyses, conductance, thermal analyses and UV-Vis techniques. Complex 1 crystallizes in triclinic crystal system, P-1 space group with a = 0.74782(7), b = 1.15082 (10), c = 1.23781(11) nm, α = 82.090(2), β= 73.011(2), γ = 83.462(2)°, V = 1.00603(16) nm3, Mr = 486.00, Z = 2, Dc= 1.604 g/cm3, final A = 0.0435, and wR = 0.1244. The structures of 1 and its related complexes show that in all the three monohuclear complexes, each Ni(II) center is penta-coordinated with a near regular square pyramid (RSP) to distorted square-pyramidal (DSP) coordination environment due to the boat/chair configuration of DACO ring in these complexes, and the degree of distortion increases with the augment of the size of the heterocyclic pendants. In addition, the most striking feature of complex 1 resides in the formation of a two-dimensional network structure through hydrogen bonds and stabilized by π-π stacking. The solution behaviors of the Ni(II) complexes are also discussed in detail.

iHMGJ6Pk.title: Crystal structure of a one-dimensional ladder-shape Co II complex through hydrogen bonds with an amino-acid-like ligand 1,5-diazacyclooctane- N , N ′-diacetate acid
iHMGJ6Pk.abstract: The crystal structure of a one-dimensional ladder-shape complex [CoL(H2O)]·2H2O, (L being 1,5-diazacyclooctane-N,N′-diacetate acid), has been determined by X-ray diffraction analysis: monoclinic, space group P21/c with a = 14.406(4) Å, b = 7.380(2) Å, c = 14.594(5) Å, β = 112.685(2)°, M r  = 341.23, V = 1431.5(8) Å3, Z = 4. The CoII center is penta-coordinated by two O atoms of the carboxylic pendant arms, two nitrogen donors of the 1,5-diazacyclooctane (DACO) moiety, and a water molecule. The coordination geometry of CoII could be described as a distorted square pyramid and the DACO backbone adopts a normal boat/chair conformation. The complex forms a one-dimensional ladder-shape structure through inter- and intra-molecular O—H···O hydrogen bonds.

14cJa3JR.title: 5,6-bis(2-pyridyl)-2,3-pyrazine-dicarbonitrile
14cJa3JR.abstract: The crystal structure of the title compound, C16H8N6, contains two independent molecules with no significant difference in their structures. The pyrazine ring makes dihedral angles of 36.7 (2) and 36.5 (3)° with the two pyridine rings in one molecule, and 43.1 (2) and 38.4 (1)° in the other. The dihedral angles between the two pyridine rings are 58.2 (2) and 56.0 (2)°, respectively. The favoured orientation of the pyridine rings is such that their N atoms face each other.
